content:
I just did this one shortest, and normally I like shortest, but this one: I spent most of the time typing the first characters of all names, seriously hoping I would not skip one, and finally having little time left to optimize further. And, luckily I directly picked the correct strategy - it would have been possible to reverse my strategy if halfway during the cases there would have been a twist requiring me the full names.
In other words: I was coding with fear rather than fun.

Most of my co-players dropped out after a couple of minutes with 0%, giving up apparently.

I see the fastest has been automatically disabled already, but frankly I would prefer this fastest over shortest.
This contribution hasn‚Äôt received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems like a good puzzle

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting and unique. Great problem!

It can be solved rapidly if the list of names is given in a format that can be used efficiently. 
e.g. in Python: a list of strings
mens = ['James', 'Robert', 'John', 'Michael', 'David', 'William', 'Richard'], etc.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this is an interesting challenge
nice idea :)

Stub generator
* Please change "top" to "topNum" for consistency.

* Please change "inits" to "initials" for consistency.

Thanks.

Done :)
(Thanks!)

Thanks for the approval.  

FYI, if you didn't know, it's easy to convert what I gave to a list of strings:
https://www.w3schools.com/python/ref_string_split.asp
Thanks üòä
Thanks !
Why were you typing the initials?  ‚ÄîThat wasn‚Äôt necessary

Well, to make it shortest. If I keep the full names in, then I am definitely not winning shortest. Or am I overlooking something? I need some list to look in, and if that list is the full names, then I have a lot of unnecessary characters, since I am looking in that list for first letters anyway. So, for shortest, my thinking was: I need to remove all characters except for the first letters of the names.

See this clash: https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/36695864eb70cad0b4cb607c0dfc9a8ab5da0bd
My code and the code of the winner are visible there.
I did not have enough time to optimize it further - which I hate :-|.

Oh, yeah, I see your point, about making it shortest.

As someone who (almost) always codes in C#, I can't take "shortest-mode" seriously, since it's impossible for a C#-coder to win.  It's always like C# user got it in 300 characters and Python-user got it in 30.

Thanks for that link.  And I see the scores and the times, but how do I see the actual code? I would be interested to see it.

And the code I would have liked to submit if I would have had a bit more time:
I=input
T=int(I())
M='JRJMDWRJTCCDMAMDSAPJKKBGTRJEJRJGNEJSLJSBBSGAPFRJDJTAJANHZDPKNEJWCKRTASGCHDALJJBBBGJLAJAWEWRVMRRBRBPE'[:T]
W='MPJLEBSJSKLNBSMAKEDMCAMDSDRSLCAKASBEAPNSKCHDRCJMCHDOJJVRVLKCJEJAHMCJMMTGSJAKASFJAJIJGADDMBCNTDBDKALM'[:T]
for i in '.'*int(I()):
 a,_,b=I().split()
 x=["don't ",''][((a in M)&(b in W))|((b in M)&(a in W))]
 print(f'{a} & {b} = {x}save')

You can use python to generate the list of initials for you rather than typing it yourself.

M='James, Robert, John, ..., Bradley, Philip, Eugene'.split(', ')
m,*_=zip(*M)
print(''.join(m))

Run any testcase with this; then the list of initials shows up in the console output and you can copy-paste it back into your code (and delete these three lines of code which you don't want in your final submission)
Oh of courseü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è, or M.split(", ") should do the job as well. Thanks for pointing it out.
You really have a lot of Ideas

Haha, it's true :)
(It's a blessing and a curse)
I guess you're right
